__data__.text: The first radio stations, WEAF and WJZ, were established by American Telephone & Telegraph (AT&T) and Westinghouse respectively. WEAF served as a research-and-development center for AT&T's audio transmission technologies, and was the first to broadcast commercially sponsored programs. In 1922, it began linking with other stations for "chain" broadcasting. RCA, the parent company of WEAF, attempted to transmit audio between cities using low-quality telegraph lines, but was unsuccessful due to interference. In 1925, AT&T sold WEAF and its embryonic network to RCA for $1 million, allowing RCA to use AT&T's phone lines for network transmission. RCA then merged WEAF with its Washington sister station WCAP and surviving station WRC, and created the National Broadcasting Company in late 1926.

AT&T sold its radio station WEAF and its network to RCA in 1925, allowing RCA to use AT&T's phone lines for network transmission. RCA then merged WEAF with its Washington station WCAP and surviving station WRC, and formed the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in late 1926, in partnership with General Electric and Westinghouse. NBC initially operated two networks, Red and Blue, which were distinguished by the color of pushpins or pencils used to designate affiliate stations. The Red Network offered commercial entertainment and music programming, while the Blue Network mostly carried non-sponsored broadcasts, such as news and cultural programs. NBC expanded to the West Coast with the launch of the NBC Orange Network in 1927 and the NBC Gold Network in 1931, which carried Red and Blue Network programming, respectively. In 1936, the Orange Network became part of the Red Network, and the Gold Network became part of the Blue Network. NBC moved its operations to 711 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan in 1927.

In the 1930s, NBC expanded its networks to the West Coast with the Orange Network, which initially recreated Red Network programming for West Coast stations. The Orange and Gold Networks later merged with the Red and Blue Networks, respectively, in 1936. NBC also established a shortwave radio network, the NBC White Network. After General Electric was charged with antitrust violations, RCA, which was once part of GE, moved to the Rockefeller Center in 1933 and became the lead tenant at the "RCA Building." The iconic three-note NBC chimes, first heard in 1931, were developed by NBC and eventually became the first audio trademark to be accepted by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. A four-note variant was used during significant events of extreme urgency. NBC moved its operations to 711 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan in 1927, but later outgrew the facilities and moved to the Rockefeller Center in 1933.

In the 1930s, NBC introduced its iconic three-note chimes, which became the first audio trademark recognized by the US Patent and Trademark Office. A four-note variant was used during urgent events, though it was not initially intended to represent General Electric. The chimes, mechanized in 1932, served as a system cue for switching stations between Red and Blue network feeds. In the late 1930s, Baltimore & Ohio Railroad gained permission to use NBC's tones to summon passengers to dinner.

Amidst concerns about monopolistic practices, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ordered RCA to sell either NBC Red or NBC Blue in 1941. This decision came after the FCC found that NBC's networks and owned-and-operated stations dominated audiences, affiliates, and advertising in American radio. Following unsuccessful appeals, RCA sold NBC Blue, which was then renamed ABC.

In 1942, NBC sold its Blue Network after an unsuccessful appeal against the FCC's order to divest due to monopolistic concerns. Blue Network was renamed to Blue Network Company, Inc., and operated as a separate entity from NBC Red, which became known as NBC. The Blue Network was sold to the American Broadcasting System, owned by Edward J. Noble, for $8 million in October 1943. Noble acquired the network's assets, including landlines, studios, contracts with actors, and agreements with affiliates. To comply with FCC's ownership limits, Noble sold his existing New York City radio station, WMCA. Noble later acquired the "American Broadcasting Company" name in 1944 and officially changed the network's name to ABC on June 15, 1945. Meanwhile, NBC's Red Network continued to host popular performers and programs, defining radio's golden age.

In 1942, NBC's Blue Network was sold and renamed to Blue Network Company, Inc., later becoming ABC in 1945. This separation was due to monopolistic concerns, and the network sold its assets, including contracts and affiliates, to American Broadcasting System, Inc. During this time, NBC Red Network continued to host popular stars and programs, defining radio's golden age. However, in the late 1940s, CBS gained popularity by allowing radio stars to use their own production companies. Consequently, many NBC performers, such as Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen, Burns and Allen, and Frank Sinatra, moved to CBS. Additionally, NBC stars began migrating to television, with Milton Berle's Texaco Star Theater becoming television's first major hit.

To keep classic radio alive and challenge CBS's Sunday night lineup, NBC launched The Big Show in 1950, featuring Tallulah Bankhead and other prestigious entertainers. This 90-minute variety show aimed to update radio's earliest musical variety style with sophisticated comedy and dramatic presentations.

The Big Show, a 90-minute variety program on NBC radio, debuted in 1950, aiming to enhance radio's original musical variety style with refined comedy and dramatic content. Starring Tallulah Bankhead, it showcased prestigious talents like Fred Allen and Ella Fitzgerald. Despite critical acclaim, the program's success was short-lived due to the growing number of television viewers. NBC lost approximately $1 million on the project, which only sold advertising time during the middle half-hour of the show each week.

Monitor, NBC's last major radio programming initiative, started on June 12, 1955, and was a continuous all-weekend mix of music, news, interviews, and features. It featured well-known television personalities and attempted to keep classic radio alive by incorporating segments from Jim and Marian Jordan (as Fibber McGee and Molly), Peg Lynch's Ethel and Albert, and Henry Morgan. Although successful for a few years, Monitor's popularity waned in the mid-1960s when local stations, especially in larger markets, were hesitant to deviate from their established formats for non-conforming network programming.

By January 26, 1975, after Monitor's 20-year run, little remained of NBC network radio beyond hourly newscasts, news features, and the Sunday morning religious program The Eternal Light. In an attempt to revive network radio, NBC launched the NBC News and Information Service (NIS) on June 18, 1975, offering up to 55 minutes of news per hour around the clock to local stations adopting an all-news radio format. This marked the decline of NBC network radio.

After the conclusion of Monitor in 1975, NBC network radio primarily consisted of hourly newscasts, news features, and The Eternal Light. To revive network radio, NBC introduced the NBC News and Information Service (NIS) in June 1975, offering extensive news coverage for local all-news radio format stations. Despite attracting several dozen subscribing stations, NIS was discontinued in 1977 due to profitability concerns. NBC later launched The Source and TalkNet, which provided news, features, and talk radio programs to FM rock stations and affiliates. However, in 1985, GE, the parent company of NBC, decided to sell off NBC's radio holdings. After a failed sale attempt, Westwood One, a California-based syndicator, bought NBC Radio Network, The Source, TalkNet, and NBC Radio Entertainment, along with leases to the radio network's facilities, for $50 million.

After GE sold NBC's radio holdings in 1985, Westwood One bought NBC Radio Network, The Source, TalkNet, and NBC Radio Entertainment. Westwood One later acquired Unistar Radio Networks and Infinity became its largest shareholder. In 1998, the Mutual/NBC newsroom closed and CBS Radio News started producing "NBC"-branded newscasts. Westwood One partnered with NBC News to launch NBC News Radio in 2003, but it was limited to one-minute newscasts on weekdays. In 2011, Westwood One was merged into Dial Global. Throughout this period, NBC-branded programming was featured and sold to various affiliates, but the network's ownership and management changed multiple times.

From 2004 to 2014, Westwood One distributed an audio simulcast of Meet the Press and collaborated with NBC News to launch NBC News Radio and NBC Sports Radio. In 2011, Westwood One merged with Dial Global, which was then acquired by Cumulus Media in 2013, causing NBC News Radio to cease operations and iHeartMedia to take over the production of NBC News Radio-branded newscasts under a licensing agreement. Historically, NBC, under David Sarnoff, was associated with selling consumer electronics, including the introduction of all-electronic television at the 1939-40 New York World's Fair.

From 1938 to 1942, DuMont Laboratories and others introduced the first home television sets, anticipating NBC's entry into television broadcasting. NBC began transmitting special events, including sports and news, primarily to bars, hotels, and public places. The first NBC Television "network" program was broadcast in 1940, featuring a play called "Meet The Wife." Despite significant promotion by RCA, television sales in New York remained low due to high costs and limited programming. The experimental period ended in 1941, allowing for commercial television broadcasts to start, with NBC's W2XBS in New York becoming the first licensed commercial station, WNBT, and airing the first paid advertisement for Bulova watches.

In 1941, NBC's station W2XBS in New York became the first licensed commercial station, WNBT, and broadcast the first paid advertisement for Bulova watches – a test pattern modified to resemble a clock with the Bulova logo. Before this, non-paid television commercials, like those for Ivory Soap, Mobilgas, and Wheaties, appeared during experimental broadcasts, such as the first MLB game on TV in 1939. Limited commercial programming was available until the U.S. entered WWII, when telecasts were reduced and later expanded as NBC prepared for post-war full-time service. During the experimental phase, WNBT aired various programs, including sports events and the first official network program, "Meet The Wife." Despite RCA's promotion, television sales in New York remained low due to high costs and limited programming.

After the U.S. entered WWII, commercial television broadcasts were limited, but expanded as NBC prepared for post-war full-time service. The first regularly scheduled program on the NBC television network was "The Voice of Firestone Televues," which aired in New York, Philadelphia, and Schenectady starting in April 1944. Another program, "The War As It Happens," began as a local show and became the first news broadcast seen in multiple cities in April 1944. On V-E Day, WNBT provided extensive news coverage, including a live pan of celebrating crowds. After the war, NBC's television network expanded from four stations, driven by the popularity of the 1947 World Series and the addition of coaxial cable connections. This period marked NBC's successful entry into the new medium.

Following WWII, NBC's television network expanded from four stations to the East Coast and Midwest through coaxial cable. In the late 1940s and early 1950s, NBC experienced success with the introduction of major stars like Milton Berle and the creation of popular shows such as Today, The Tonight Show, and Wide Wide World. NBC commissioned Gian Carlo Menotti to compose the first television opera, Amahl and the Night Visitors, which aired from 1951 to 1966. Despite CBS's early attempts at color television, NBC was prepared with color programming when the RCA-compatible color system became the U.S. standard in 1953.

After CBS's unsuccessful attempts at color television, NBC quickly adopted the RCA-compatible color system and began broadcasting color programs in 1954. A notable early production was the live broadcast of Peter Pan in 1955, which was so successful that it was restaged twice. NBC established a subsidiary, California National Productions (CNP), for merchandising and syndication operations, and in 1956, WNBQ in Chicago became the first station to air color broadcasts daily. The Bell Telephone Hour, a televised version of a popular radio program, began airing in color in 1959. In 1961, NBC approached Walt Disney to acquire the rights to his anthology series, offering to produce it in color.

In 1959, NBC launched the color broadcast of The Bell Telephone Hour, which ran until 1968. In 1961, NBC, having the capability to produce color programs, approached Walt Disney for his anthology series, which ABC could not match due to a lack of resources. Consequently, Disney moved the show to NBC, which aired it as Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color. NBC's Rose Bowl telecast in 1962 was the first college football game in color. By 1963, most of NBC's prime time schedule was in color, and in 1965, it was broadcasting 95% of its prime time schedule in color, branding itself as "The Full Color Network." NBC also produced the first feature-length film for television in 1964 and acquired the rights to The Wizard of Oz in 1967.

In the late 1960s, NBC started targeting younger audiences and phasing out older-skewing shows, such as The Bell Telephone Hour and Sing Along With Mitch, to attract advertisers. During this time, NBC acquired the rights to broadcast The Wizard of Oz in 1967, which CBS had previously aired with a hosted introduction and in color since 1956. However, by 1967, color broadcasts were common, and NBC aired the film without an introduction, slightly editing it for commercials. Despite the edits, it remained popular until CBS reacquired the rights in 1976, as they had realized their mistake in letting go of a major ratings success. NBC's shift in programming practices was a response to the growing influence of the baby boomer generation.

In the late 1960s, NBC aimed to attract younger audiences and modernize their programming by targeting adults aged 18-49, considering shows like The Bell Telephone Hour and Sing Along With Mitch too old-fashioned with an average viewer age of 50. The network found success with new shows in the 1970s, but later experienced a slump due to unsuccessful attempts to draw younger viewers with expensive movies, miniseries, and specials, which also alienated older viewers. Despite introducing new prime-time shows in 1975, none received a second season renewal. NBC's sole breakout success was the late-night comedy/variety show, Saturday Night Live. In 1978, NBC, still struggling, lured Fred Silverman from top-rated ABC to revive their fortunes.

Under Silverman's leadership in the late 1970s, NBC saw limited success with shows like CHiPs, Barbara Mandrell and the Mandrell Sisters, Diff'rent Strokes, The Facts of Life, Real People, and Shōgun, while many other shows failed and lost viewership to competitors. Consequently, several long-time NBC affiliates switched to ABC and CBS, contributing to NBC's ongoing struggles.

During Silverman's tenure at NBC in the late 1970s, the network experienced mixed results with successful shows like CHiPs and Diff'rent Strokes, but also faced significant losses and defections of affiliates, particularly VHF stations, to ABC and CBS. This was due to NBC's limited success in comparison to its competitors. In response, NBC had to affiliate with UHF stations in several markets, some of which later became NBC O&Os or rejoined the network. However, some markets like El Dorado, Green Bay, and Bakersfield eventually switched to other networks. This period was marked by a significant reshuffling of network affiliations and a shift towards UHF stations.

During Silverman's tenure at NBC in the late 1970s, the network faced challenges with failing shows and loss of affiliates, causing a reshuffling of network affiliations and a shift towards UHF stations. The cancellation of 1980 Summer Olympics coverage due to the US team withdrawal further exacerbated the situation, leading to negative press and internal criticism. An example includes a parody song "Loud as a Peacock" by NBC's promotional theme composer and a satirical sketch on SNL by Al Franken. Silverman's resignation followed, and Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff took over, inheriting a struggling schedule. Tartikoff, however, demonstrated patience with promising shows like the critically acclaimed Hill Street Blues, which initially suffered from poor ratings.

After Silverman's resignation, Grant Tinker, a well-regarded producer, became the president of NBC, and Brandon Tartikoff took over as the president of the entertainment division. They inherited a struggling network with poor-performing shows and the cancellation of the 1980 Summer Olympics coverage. Tartikoff demonstrated patience with promising programs like the critically acclaimed Hill Street Blues, which initially had weak ratings. He moved the show to Thursdays, where its ratings improved significantly. Similar tactics were used for St. Elsewhere and Cheers.

During this period, NBC found success with The A-Team, its only program to rank in the Nielsen Top-20 for the 1982-83 season. Late Night with David Letterman, which started in 1982, also became a significant success, serving as the launching pad for another late-night talk franchise.

The turning point came in 1984 when The Cosby Show's massive success led to renewed interest in sitcoms. Family Ties and Cheers, both of which initially had mediocre ratings, saw increased viewership after being aired as lead-ins for The Cosby Show. NBC's ratings improved from third place to second in the 1984-85 season and reached first place in 1985-86 with hits like The Golden Girls, Miami Vice, 227, Night Court, Highway to Heaven, and Hunter.

Following Silverman's resignation, Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff took over NBC, which was in a poor state with underperforming shows. They turned the network around by patiently nurturing successful programs, like Hill Street Blues, despite initial weak ratings. Late Night with David Letterman also became a significant success. The turning point was The Cosby Show's massive success in 1984, which led to a resurgence of sitcoms and elevated NBC's ratings.

By 1985, NBC's ratings improved to second place and reached first place in 1985-86 with shows like The Golden Girls, Miami Vice, 227, Night Court, Highway to Heaven, and Hunter. The network's success continued with ALF, Amen, Matlock, L.A. Law, The Hogan Family, A Different World, Empty Nest, Unsolved Mysteries, and In the Heat of the Night.

In 1986, Bob Wright became the chairman of NBC, and the network started broadcasting programs in stereo. NBC also mended its relationships with previously lost affiliates and launched a syndication package for its owned-and-operated stations, consisting of five sitcoms, including Marblehead Manor, She's the Sheriff, You Can't Take It with You, Out of This World, and a revival of We Got It Made.

After Silverman's resignation, Grant Tinker and Brandon Tartikoff revived NBC with successful shows like Hill Street Blues and Late Night with David Letterman, culminating in the massive success of The Cosby Show in 1984. By 1985, NBC's ratings improved to second place and reached first place in 1985-86 with shows like The Golden Girls, Miami Vice, and others. In 1986, Bob Wright became the chairman, and the network started broadcasting programs in stereo.

In the same year, NBC tested the sitcom checkerboard concept on KCRA in Sacramento, consisting of five different sitcoms aimed at attracting viewers before prime time. This concept was made possible by the FCC's loosening of the Prime Time Access Rule and the relaxation of the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules. However, these sitcoms often underperformed compared to syndicated game shows.

In 1987, NBC planned to increase output of in-house productions, including half-hour dramedies, and experimented with a sitcom lineup for Thanksgiving weekend. Low ratings for NBC's daytime lineup were attributed to the creation of the new soap opera, Generations, set for spring 1988.

The sitcom checkerboard package initially included The New Gidget, One Big Family, Mama's Family, Throb, and It's a Living. Of these, Mama's Family and It's a Living were syndicated revivals of network sitcoms that had been canceled earlier in the decade. Marblehead Manor, We Got It Made, and You Can't Take It With You were canceled at the end of the 1987-88 season, while She's the Sheriff lasted one more season in weekend syndication before its cancellation. Out of This World was the most successful of the five series, running for three additional seasons mainly on weekends.

In the late 1980s and early 1990s, NBC underwent significant changes, including the integration of NBC Enterprises with NBC-TV and Corporate Communications. NBC also began airing the Summer Olympic Games, starting with the 1988 Seoul Games, and experienced great success with 17 series in Nielsen's year-end Top 30 most-watched network programs in the 1988-89 season. The network's streak continued with new hits like "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," "Blossom," and "Law & Order."

Brandon Tartikoff, NBC's President of Entertainment, played a crucial role during this period, transforming the network from having no shows in the Nielsen Top 10 to having five by the time he left for Paramount Pictures in 1991. Warren Littlefield succeeded Tartikoff, facing initial challenges due to the conclusion of many Tartikoff-era hits. One of Tartikoff's late acquisitions, "Seinfeld," struggled at first but eventually became one of NBC's top-rated shows.

The network's success continued through the early 1990s, with the launches of shows like "Mad About You," "Wings," "Sisters," "Frasier," "Friends," "ER," and "Will & Grace." However, NBC's hot streak was not without setbacks, such as losing David Letterman to CBS and the end of its long-standing relationship with Major League Baseball in 1989.

In the late 1990s, "Seinfeld" ended its successful run as the leading TV show in Nielsen ratings, followed by "Friends" taking over as NBC's top program. "Frasier," a "Cheers" spin-off, also became a hit, often ranking in the Nielsen Top 20, although its ratings were somewhat overshadowed by "Friends." NBC started branding its powerful Thursday night lineup, including popular comedies, as "Must See TV" in 1994, which later expanded to other nights. During this time, NBC also affiliated with several stations due to the 1994-96 broadcast TV realignment caused by Fox acquiring NFL rights.

In the mid-'90s, NBC's affiliations changed due to broadcast realignments involving Westinghouse, CBS, New World Communications, Fox, Allbritton, and SF Broadcasting, affecting stations like WBAL-TV, WHDH, WCAU, KSHB-TV, WCBD-TV, WGBA-TV, WPMI-TV, and KHNL. Simultaneously, NBC Sports, led by Dick Ebersol, held rights to the NFL, MLB, NBA, Olympics, and Notre Dame football. The NBA on NBC thrived because of the Chicago Bulls' success with Michael Jordan. However, NBC Sports faced a significant setback in 1998 when it lost AFC rights to CBS, ending its 59-year relationship with the NFL and 36-year partnership with AFC.

During this period, Warren Littlefield, president of NBC Entertainment, left the network in 1998 to become a TV and film producer. NBC subsequently had three entertainment presidents in three years: Scott Sassa, Garth Ancier, and Jeff Zucker. Sassa developed shows like The West Wing, Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, and Fear Factor.

At the dawn of the 21st century, NBC's ratings lead ended, with CBS, which had previously struggled after losing the NFL, taking first place.

In the early 2000s, NBC's ratings lead ended, with CBS taking first place, marking the potential end of NBC's nearly two-decade dominance on Thursday nights. Despite the success of shows like Friends, Will & Grace, ER, and Just Shoot Me!, NBC implemented letterbox formatting to attract new viewers, with minimal success. Between 2001-2005, NBC regained the top spot in ratings, excluding the 2002-2003 season when CBS briefly led. Concurrently, NBC lost broadcast rights for Major League Baseball and the NBA, retaining only the Olympics, PGA Tour golf events, and a struggling Notre Dame football program. In October 2001, NBC acquired Telemundo for $2.7 billion, outbidding CBS/Viacom.

After losing its ratings lead in the early 2000s, NBC made several changes, including acquiring Telemundo and merging with Vivendi Universal Entertainment to form NBC Universal. However, the network faced challenges as popular shows like "Friends" and "Frasier" ended, and new shows like "Joey" struggled. NBC's ratings fell to fourth place by the 2005-06 season, despite the success of the game show "Deal or No Deal." The network also lost broadcast rights for Major League Baseball, the NBA, and had a struggling Notre Dame football program, retaining only the Olympics, PGA Tour golf events, and a struggling Notre Dame football program. In 2004, NBC acquired the rights to the National Hockey League.

After losing its top position, NBC tried to boost its ratings by acquiring Telemundo and merging with Vivendi Universal Entertainment to form NBC Universal. However, the network faced challenges due to the conclusion of popular shows and the failure of new ones. NBC's ratings dropped to fourth place by the 2005-06 season, even with successful shows like "Deal or No Deal." The network lost broadcast rights for various sports, retaining only the Olympics, PGA Tour golf events, and a struggling Notre Dame football program. In 2004, NBC acquired National Hockey League rights.

During this period, all networks faced audience erosion due to increased competition from cable TV, home videos, video games, and the Internet. NBC was hit hardest, but managed to regain NFL broadcast rights in 2006. Despite the success of "Deal or No Deal," "Heroes," "The Office," and "30 Rock," NBC struggled and remained in fourth place.

Summer schedules proved successful for NBC, with "America's Got Talent" earning high ratings in 2006. However, NBC did not air it during the spring and instead used it to promote fall shows.

In 2007, Kevin Reilly was replaced by Ben Silverman as president of NBC Entertainment, and Jeff Zucker took over as CEO of NBC, succeeding Bob Wright.

After NBC's ratings dropped to fourth place, the network attempted to boost its position by acquiring Telemundo and merging with Vivendi Universal Entertainment to form NBC Universal. However, they continued to struggle due to the loss of sports broadcast rights and the failure of many new shows. Kevin Reilly was replaced by Ben Silverman as president of NBC Entertainment, and Jeff Zucker became CEO of NBC in 2007. Despite having the rights to the Super Bowl and the Summer Olympics, NBC failed to generate new primetime hits. The sitcom "Parks and Recreation" was an exception, surviving for a second season. "Heroes" and "Deal or No Deal" both experienced a decline in ratings and were eventually canceled. In 2009, Ben Silverman left the network and Jeff Gaspin took over as president of NBC Entertainment. Comcast purchased a 51% controlling stake in NBC Universal in December 2009. NBC's broadcast of the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver saw a 21% increase in ratings compared to the 2006 games, but the network was criticized for repeatedly showing footage of a fatal luge crash. Despite this, NBC Universal was still projected to lose $250 million in advertising revenue for the 2010 Winter Olympics.

After NBC's failure to improve its fourth-place ranking and the cancellation of several shows, including "Heroes" and "Law & Order," the network attempted to revamp its prime time lineup by replacing scripted dramas with The Jay Leno Show at 10:00 p.m. This move was criticized by industry executives and NBC affiliates, leading to the cancellation of Leno's show in the 10:00 p.m. slot and a reshuffling of the late-night lineup. Despite the success of the 2010 Winter Olympics, NBC Universal was still projected to lose $250 million in advertising revenue for the games. At the end of the 2009-10 season, only a few shows, such as "Community" and "Parks and Recreation," were renewed for second seasons. NBC News also refused to show footage of a fatal luge crash during the Olympics coverage.

Following the criticism of airing The Jay Leno Show at 10:00 p.m., NBC moved it to the 11:35 p.m. slot, reshuffling the late-night lineup. However, this change had minimal impact on the network's ratings, which continued to struggle despite the success of NBC Sunday Night Football and the 2010 Winter Olympics. Comcast took over a majority interest in NBC Universal in late 2010, leading to management changes, including Steve Burke becoming CEO and Robert Greenblatt as chairman of NBC Entertainment. The network's fortunes remained mixed, with the cancellation of all new fall programs in 2011, except for Harry's Law, and a successful midseason lineup of The Voice and Smash. NBC's broadcast of Super Bowl XLVI in 2012 was the most-watched program in U.S. television history at the time.

NBC's broadcast of Super Bowl XLVI and the success of The Voice, Smash, and Sunday Night Football helped the network rank third in the 18-49 demographic in the 2011-12 season, breaking its eight-year streak in fourth place. However, the network's midseason ratings fell, and it remained a distant fourth in total viewership. In the fall of 2012, NBC expanded its sitcom roster and returned to first place in the 18-49 demographic. Despite a decline in midseason ratings, the network finished the 2012-13 season in third place. The 2013-14 season was successful for NBC due to the continued success of its established shows, new hits, and the ratings boost from the 2014 Winter Olympics, making it the No. 1 network. However, a highly advertised game show event, The Million Second Quiz, was unsuccessful. NBC Sports also migrated its operations to new facilities in Connecticut.

In the 2013-14 season, NBC maintained the success of its shows like The Voice, Chicago Fire, and The Blacklist, and introduced new hits such as The Blacklist, Hannibal, and Chicago PD. The network also gained a significant ratings boost from the 2014 Winter Olympics, making it the No. 1 network in the 18-49 demographic. Although the network launched eight new series in the 2014-15 season and only one was renewed, NBC still finished first in the 18-49 demographic and second overall due to the success of returning series and the Super Bowl XLIX viewership. The 2015-16 season was successful for NBC with the launch of Blindspot and Chicago Med, while Thursday nights remained a challenge with the cancellation of Heroes Reborn and the success of Shades of Blue.

In the 2016-17 season, NBC found success with the premiere of "This Is Us" and the continuation of "The Blacklist," despite the cancellation of its spinoff. The network also expanded the "Chicago" franchise with a third spinoff, "Chicago Justice." On the comedy side, "Superstore" and newcomer "The Good Place" performed well, while "The Wall" brought in modest summer ratings. The 2017-18 season saw the return of "Will & Grace" and the success of "Ellen's Game of Games." The 2018-19 season brought premieres of several successful shows, including "Manifest," "Songland," and "New Amsterdam," but "The Village" and "The Enemy Within" were not renewed. However, the network's success began to decline in the 2019-20 season due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which disrupted production and caused the postponement of the 2020 Summer Olympics.

The COVID-19 pandemic in 2019-20 disrupted NBC's programming production, leading to the postponement of the 2020 Summer Olympics and a drop in the Nielsen ratings. However, NBC rebounded and regained its position as the top-rated network in 2022. The pandemic marked the end of NBC's dominance in the 2010s.
